subject: Re: [junit] Why bother?
msgSnippet: 1) You want to ship the code in main and burden your released system with additional memory consumption? 2) My experience is that most people will write a main
messageBody:
1) You want to ship the code in main and burden your released system with
additional memory consumption?

2) My experience is that most people will write a main that does NOT
automatically say, "yes, I passed all my tests". They generally will print
out results, rather than asserting the truth. The automatic behavior in
unit tests is key.

3) Inevitably, as you write hundreds of tests, you find commonality, which
should be refactored out into supporting classes. Junit has already done
this, to some degree, for you.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Yishay Mor" <ymor@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, June 10, 2001 6:02 PM
Subject: [junit] Why bother?


> Help me out, please -
>
>
> I'm trying to "market" JUnit to my team. The most common objection I get
goes along the line of "what advantage will I get out of this, when writing
my code? I have my test class, w/ its main(..) method, and that's all I
need."
> Even though people are willing to see the advantage of a unit testing
framework for the long term project development, that want to see "personal
value".
>
